Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP failed to achieve compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION: On 10/31/20, residents at the facility went trick or treating and staff
did not check candy that was obtained. Resident with special needs and various
allergies consumed peanuts, had reaction, and required medical attention.
INVESTIGATION:
It was alleged the facility did not check the Trick or Treat candy Youth A received and
Youth A ate some candy that contained peanuts, that Youth A is allergic to and Youth A
had to receive medical treatment for an allergic reaction.
2

I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 by telephone on 11/12/2020. Foster Care Worker 1
is the foster care worker for Youth A. Foster Care Worker 1 stated the facility did a
special bag of treats for Youth A due to Youth A’s allergies. Foster Care Worker 1
stated Youth A knows what he is allergic to and Foster Care Worker 1 was currently in
transit to see Youth A. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she had requested an Incident
Report of the situation but had not yet received an incident report.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 11/13/2020. Youth A alleged he did not have a
special bag of treats and the youth did not swap treats with each other. Youth A stated
he is allergic to peanuts, eggs, and seafood. Youth A stated he ate some treats
containing peanuts, Reese Peanut Butter Cups, and Butterfingers. Youth A stated
nothing happened, but the facility gave Youth A some Benadryl.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 11/13/2020. Staff 1 stated she was one of the staff
members that made the special treat bag for Youth A due to Youth A’s allergies. Staff 1
stated the bags were given to the youth on Friday and the youth began swapping the
contents of their bags with each other on Friday evening. Staff 1 stated Youth A said on
Saturday that he didn’t feel right. The facility staff contacted Great Lakes Bay medical
provider after hours and they were told to monitor Youth A for any allergic reaction
symptoms and give Youth A some Benadryl. Staff 1 stated Youth A was given Benadryl
and Youth A did not demonstrate any symptoms.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 11/13/2020. Staff 2 stated an incident report was
completed and Youth A was given Benadryl but the dispensing of the Benadryl to Youth
A was not logged/documented as required by the facility’s health care policies.
On 11/13/2020 I received a copy of the incident report that was completed. Information
on the incident report indicated the incident occurred on 10/31/2020 and a copy of the
report was faxed to Foster Care Worker 1 on 11/02/2020. The report also indicated
Youth A was given Benadryl on 10/31/2020 as directed by Great Lakes Bay Health.
I participated in a PCU telephone conference with State Worker 1 on 11/30/2020 and
shared my preliminary findings as a part of that conference.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
3

ANALYSIS: The findings of this investigation determined this incident did not
require the facility to contact Foster Care Worker 1 immediately
for compliance with licensing rules and the supervision policies
of this facility. The findings did determine Foster Care Worker 1
was notified and given/faxed a copy of the completed incident
report. Youth A was given the appropriate medical treatment
consistent with the need of Youth A.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(c) Documentation of medical care and maintenance of
health records.
ANALYSIS: The findings of this investigation indicated the dispensing of the
Benadryl medication to Youth A was not documented in the
healthcare record of Youth A as required for compliance with the
health care policies and procedures of this facility.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend the continuation
of the 1st provisional license status of this child care institution- private.
